heading: programmers took leap of faith
subheading: worried about what to worry about once the y2k threat passes safely into memory? look no further. a new leap-year computer glitch threatens to ruin your entire march.
author: wired news report
text: just when it was starting to feel like the y2k scare was almost behind us, reports of another computer glitch have emerged, threatening to ruin your whole march. y2k officials admitted that a leap-year bug could cause problems starting 29 february 2000 -- the first "leap day" in a turn-of-the-century year since 1600, according to a washington times article.in an interview with abc's "this week," y2k czar john koskinen, chairman of the president's council on year 2000 conversion, acknowledged the potential for computer-related problems in the first months of the new century, due to a calendar oversight.the first year of a new century is "not a leap year, unless it's divisible by 400," koskinen said. "and it turns out enough people didn't understand that, that they programmed year 2000 as a non-leap year," when it actually is a leap year.koskinen said that his team would take similar -- though not quite as extensive -- precautions for the leap-year glitch as they did for y2k. "we will monitor whatever happens on the 29th, just the way we are monitoring what happens over the weekend of january 1st," he said.a spokesman for the president's council on the year 2000 told the washington times that the leap-year glitch posed little threat, since most computers that had tested for the y2k bug had also tested for the leap-year bug.
